content:
The statement is not clear about what to do when there are multiple different anagrams. For example if the input lines were "arc", "car", "bad", "dab", should the output be 2 or 4? It would also be good to specify that you mean anagrams of lines instead of words, preferably with a full example.

Additionally one of the "no anagram" cases should be a test case (rather than a validator).

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it's well done and there is plenty of solutions possible to finish the contribution under 5-15 min

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is very clear and it's fun to work on string comparison. The anagram is a very interesting approach :)

Goal/Input sections
* Not really "sentences" in most cases... Just "strings".
* Please specify that case  and spaces should be ignored when determining whether the strings are anagrams.

Input section
* You may remove the first part "Number of sentences". The second part (i.e. An integer [[N]] etc) is sufficient.
* Please format [[n]] in "next n lines".

Output section
* Please change "Ligne" to "Line".

Constraints section
* I think the lower bound of N should be set as 2 instead of 1, because having N = 1 means there's nothing to compare really.
* Suggest to specify that all strings consist of letters and spaces only.

Output requirement
* As per contribution guidelines, binary output should be avoided in a clash of code:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
Please revise the output requirement so that there are more than 2 possible answers in total for all cases.
Maybe instead of just TRUE or FALSE, ask the player to output the maximum number of strings that form the same anagram, e.g. output is 2 for "arc", "car" and "care" as input. (Just a suggestion, you may use other ideas.)

Thanks.
Thanks for your comment. I will edit my text
It's not just the text. Binary output is the major issue.
Thanks, I hadn't found the time to make an update, it's done now.

OK.

Please update the write statement (e.g. "write answer" instead of "write TRUE").

I would also suggest to swap Validator 1 with Test 4, so that the test and validator which require 0 as the output are paired together.

Thanks again.
0 should be formatted as a {{constant}}, not a [[variable]]. Thanks.
